description: I really want Jami to work, and if you're using it amongst a group of senior software developers or nerdy friends who really want to dig into P2P video calling and chatting, this is for you. If you want to run conference calls with your companions or co-workers who are average to below-average in technical prowess, you're going to be providing a LOT of technical support to your group, including being the host, understanding things like "rendezvous account", reading abstract blog entries written by developers with little practical guidance, understanding detailed settings, figuring out why everyone's audio is working but video is a black screen (this time, but it worked fine last time), etc. So, if having your calls routed through a company's servers isn't a huge blocker for you, and/or you need reliability, you're, unfortunately, probably better off with Zoom, Slack or Teams. Why am I rating it 4 stars then? Because it does P2P texting and conference calling, and that's really how those things should be done, so if the product isn't as smooth as one by a billion-dollar-a-year company that also probably sells your data and pushes ads and political bias on you constantly, they still deserve at least four stars for it.
summary: Great concept, hard to use, buggy

description:
i feel that this not good in wayland because this app crashes when i add the pulgins to it. also the most annoying problem is that there is no option to add other with an email address instead the people who like to join with you on video chat or meeting they should have this app on there machine, which is very much annoying. 

also this app doesnt have that web interface where other's can join from the browser. 

I did tested this on my machine and I should mention that these developers in GNU are the best but i feel that they lag in most of the normal and utterly basics when it comes to app creation for free.

now I'm removing this app but I will install this again to test and see if these are added to this app. Also i will try to contribute to the gitbub page.
summary: it crashes most of the time

description: Well, I downloaded it along with a client of mine. We got the app to work, but only the voice worked...and only for a short time. After that, the voice part came in horribly scrambled. The video portion never worked. So, it's getting deleted for now. I have high hopes that this will be better sooner rather than later. Would LOVE to use this as opposed to Microsoft Teams.
summary: Voice works, but that's about it..

description:
Jami staff confirmed that Jami is a GNU package, distributed under the GPLv3 license. 
The Jami package distributed by Ubuntu is not up-to-date and the license type mentioned is incorrect.
You can install Jami by following the instructions on Jami website, to always have the latest version. https://jami.net/download-jami-linux/
However in April 2020 the downloadable installer for linux ubuntu from the website (once clicked on to install) suggested the licence was proprietary – this is an oversight where developers have forgotten to update. Once installed the information about Jami shows the licence as GPL.
working on 18.04 but lack of test / echo account, or user directory

Kein Telefon, kein nichts.
Ist einfach da und belastet CPU und Speicher.

Nicht genügend Parameter vorhanden.
SIP-Server benötigen in der Regel:
- Login-Namen
- Nutzer-Namen (Leitungsauswahl)
- Passwort

Der Nutzer-Namen oder die Leitungswahl fehlen.
SIP Einstellungen die bei anderen Clients funktionieren, funktionieren hier nicht. Es wird zwar eine Netzwerkverbindung angezeigt, ein Call wird aber sofirt mit Fehler abgebrochen.

Jami est une solution de vidéoconférence sans serveur central activement développée.
Installation recommandée via https://jami.net pour pouvoir profiter de la grande fréquence des mises à jour.
Une application prometteuse à partager et à surveiller de près. Ce qui n'est pas parfait aujourd'hui le sera probablement demain.
summary: La future vedette de la vidéoconférence

description: This application is really awesome and strongly underrated! It could be used instead of Skype and other similar call/video tools. Unfortunately, developers (Savoir-Faire Linux) do not proceed with updates for Arch-based distros and focus mainly on Debian-based distributions. However, it is highly recommended!
